   INTERNATIONAL

   MEXICO-HUMANRIGHTS MEXICO CITY _ Pressure is mounting for
Mexican President-elect Vicente Fox to look into Mexico's record of
human rights abuses. Prompted by the recent arrest of an Argentine
here suspected of torture in his home country, a group of people
with ``disappeared'' family members have resurrected their own
fight for justice. They accuse high-ranking officials of the
Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) of repressive acts over the
party's 71-year rule. Pressure is also on to review other cases _ a
peasant environmentalist and an Army colonel _ human rights group
believe are unjustly imprisoned now.

   WAN: Location, Atlanta; Category, International; Subcategory,
Other.

   WRITER/EDITOR: (Ferriss, Cox News Service) WITH PHOTOS

   RUSSIA-INTERNET MOSCOW _ Under a new law, every communications
and Internet provider in Russia must install a program designed by
the Federal Security Service, or FSB, to allow the intelligence
agency to monitor e-mail and Internet traffic by users. Not only
does the Internet provider have to allow the FSB access to their
network, but the companies have to pay for the installation and
training for these officers to do their dirty work. Human rights
organizations are up in arms, arguing it's a further sign that the
country has slipped back into a Soviet mode of control. (Coker, Cox
News Service) WITH PHOTOS.

   ISRAEL-DEFENSE _ JERUSALEM _ In a country flush with military
bravado, it figures that Israeli tourist shops would offer an array
of army ball caps and fatigue T-shirts. ``America don't worry,''
quips one T-shirt around a drawing of an F-16 jet. ``Israel is
behind you.'' In truth, of course, it's the other way around.
American aid makes up about a quarter of Israel's defense budget,
including nearly half its equipment, comes free from America. But,
even as Israeli officials prepare to ask for increases in aid with
President Clinton's encouragement, some say that Israel's defense
dependence on American aid may be doing more harm than good. WAN:
Location, Atlanta; Category, International; Subcategory, Other.

   (Kaplow, Cox News Service)

   ISRAEL-USAID _ TEL AVIV _ Israel, which has a per capita income
greater and Greece and Spain, receives some $3 billion from the
United States annually _ about a quarter of the total U.S. aid
budget. With a possible Mideast peace on the horizon, that figure
could grow by billions more over the next decade. But should it?
Analysts, officials and American Israel backers see the aid as an
investment that reaps priceless returns. A growing number of that
same group are beginning to question Israel's reliance on American
largesse, however. (Kaplow, Cox News Service)

   NATION

   CENSUS-ADJUST _ A federal lawsuit against the state of Virginia
is emerging as the all-important test case in the politically
charged issue of whether states next year can use raw census
results instead of statistically adjusted counts to redraw
legislative districts. A dozen major U.S. cities and counties have
joined the fight against a Virginia law passed this year by the
GOP-dominated legislature. Urban areas, with large minority
populations traditionally undercounted by the census, fear the
Virginia law will set a national precedent. (Holmes, Cox News
Service)

   Eds: Moving Thursday.

   WAN: Atlanta, National, U.S. Government

   SLAUGHTER-HONORS _ATLANTA _ J. C. Slaughter, 78, a black veteran
of World War II who won the purple heart and combat infantry badge,
was court martialed and dishonorably discharged after he refused a
direct order to return to the front lines. Slaughter was seriously
wounded and knew he'd be unable to keep up with his unit. Rcently,
through his daughter's efforts, the Army reopened Slaughter's case
and exonerated him, giving him an honorable discharge and veteran's
benefits. (Davis, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   VA-SENATE _ The Senate race in Virginia is shaping up as one of
the tightest in the country and a key factor in control of the
chamber next year. A veteran Democrat, incumbent Charles Robb, is
facing a popular former Republican governor, George Allen. (Dart,
Cox News Service)

   CHENEY _WASHINGTON _ Cursory looks at Dick Cheney's voting
record reveal a very conservative record on certain social issues.
But examining his full record across a broad spectrum illustrates
he was even more of a voice in the wilderness. (Sherman, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   TEEPEN-COLUMN _ George W. Bush is back in full-smirk mode now
that he's muddled the issue over presidential campaign debates. He
appears to think he has muddled it successfully, and perhaps he
has.Didn't Al Gore say he would debate Bush any time anywhere and
isn't he now, just as Bush charges, refusing to do just that?
Indeed. But Gore's rhetorical sally assumed Bush would first buy
into the debates that the presidential debate commission would set
up. After all, every candidate since 1988 had, including daddy
Bush. (Tom Teepen is national correspondent for Cox Newspapers.)
MOVES THURSDAY.

   KLEINBERG-COLUMN _ All along I knew that Patty the Postal Lady
was not a latent killer. Patty delivers the mail to my house.
Often, we chat. Sometimes about the rock music she has bellowing
from the portable radio in her little truck, sometimes about other
things. But I never envisioned that one troubled day she would show
up back at the post office, automatic weapon in hand, and
rat-a-tat-tat a bunch of co-workers. (Kleinberg, Cox News Service.)
MOVED THURSDAY.

   GLASS-COLUMN _ (Andy Glass is a columnist for Cox News Service
in the Washington bureau.) MOVES THURSDAY.

   DAYTON END OF LIFE SERIES

   Beginning Sunday, the Dayton Daily News begins a five-part
series called ``Letting Go: Choices at the end of life.'' It's all
about end-of-life issues, from hospice care to talking to doctors
and families, support groups and health industry issues.

   The series is running in conjunction with a PBS Series by Bill
Moyers called ``On Our Terms'' that is running in most markets from
Sunday, Sept. 10 through Wednesday Sept. 13, but the stories can
stand alone.

   The stories will be available via the Budget Tool with a run
date that corresponds to the day the story is moving.

   Elements from the series will be used for the CoxNet HEALTHY
LIVING page for Tuesday, Sept, 19. That page will be available on
Friday, Sept. 15 at 2 p.m.

   Series stories include:

   SUNDAY, SEPT. 10

   END-LETTINGGO _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Scene-setter for the series. 17
inches (Lamb, Dayton Daily News)

   WITH

   END-OF-LIFE _ DAYTON, Ohio _ The morning after Chuck Gross's
90th birthday bash, he woke up with severe chest pain from a
fracture in his spine. His doctor guessed it had been caused by the
spread of his prostate cancer, first diagnosed eight years before.
But Gross declined to be treated or even tested for metastatic
disease. He felt the time had come to leave this life gracefully,
and on his own terms. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 80 inches

   WITH PHOTOS

   WITH

   END-PBS _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Beginning at 9 p.m. CT Sunday and
continuing at 9 p.m. CT Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, WPTD,
Channel 16, will air On Our Own Terms: Moyers on Dying. This PBS
series by Bill and Judith Davidson Moyers examines the options
available for the terminally ill. The series will be repeated at
various times throughout the week. Each part focuses on different
topics. (Dayton Daily News)

   WITH

   END-OF-LIFE-SIDE _ DAYTON, Ohio _ An incredibly complete list of

   MONDAY, SEPT. 11

   END-DYING _ DAYTON, Ohio _ The cost of dying. Trying to keep
people alive in the last months of life is bankrupting our health
care system as scientific advances outpace our ability to pay for
them. But the alternative of allocating what we do and don't pay
for raises lots of thorny ethical issues. Local health care
organizations have put together a consortium of ethicists to
address these problems, and we talk to them about a number of
issues. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 45 to 50 inches. WITH PHOTO

   END-DIRECTIVES _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Living wills, advance
directives, durable powers of attorney. What are they and what do
you need to be doing to make sure your wishes about dying are
followed. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News)15 inches

   END-SERIES _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Short story explaining the Bill
Moyers' series, with a how to watch box. (Dayton Daily News)

   END-SERIESBOX _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Furniture about the series,
what's coming up. (Dayton Daily News)

   TUESDAY, SEPT. 12

   END-DRDEATH _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Doctors are trained to prevent
death, not cooperate with it. The result is that they're at
cross-purposes with hospice care. By overestimating life
expectancies, they both mislead patients and families and disable
the hospice concept. It's generally agreed that doctors need more
training in end-of life care, particularly the pain-relief and
psychological aspects, but aside from that, there is an honest
dispute as to where doctors belong on the spectrum from defying
death to embracing hospice care. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 50
inches

   WEDNESDAY, SEPT. 13

   END-MONEYSTRAIN _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Doctors didn't discover Sandra
Lee Hughes' lung cancer until the disease had reached her brain and
paralyzed her legs. At 43, and with two young daughters in her
care, Hughes suddenly had no job and no family support system at a
time when she was facing a terminal disease. She called on her
estranged husband, an unemployed Fairborn resident from whom she
had been separated for six years. He moved her from Alabama to his
home in Fairborn, where family members, including Hughes'
14-year-old daughter, Jennifer, took turns caring for her in a
tiny, ramshackle house. For hours at a time, Jennifer found herself
alone with her mother and, at times, no food to eat. A family
doctor recommended Hospice of Dayton, and soon the agency's home
health aides were there not only to care for Hughes but to make
sure there was enough medical supplies and food in the home.
Hospice never charged the family a penny, but the agency must rely
on donations from the community to help families like Sandra's.
Once she saw that her daughters would be taken care of, Hughes
decided to let go, calling out to Jennifer one night to say
``goodbye.'' (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily News) 25 inches

   WITH PHOTO

   WITH

   END-MONEYSTRAINSIDE _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Tips on how to ease the
financial strain and utilize community resources for families
dealing with the death of a loved one. (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily
News) 10 inches

   WITH

   END-VETS _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Harold Johnson served his country
proudly in Vietnam as an infantry sergeant, only to be exposed by
his own government to a toxic chemical, Agent Orange, that years
later would lead to lung cancer. Johnson, 51, is now in the end
stages of that disease. He says he's no longer bitter about what
happened to him in Vietnam, and that he looks forward to ``meeting
the Lord.'' And he's also grateful to the hospice and palliative
care program at the Dayton VA, which has provided his end-of-life
care free of charge. The VA here wants to get the word out: it
provides a wide array of end-of-life services to eligible veterans,
and at no cost. (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily News) 25 inches. WITH PHOTO

Moyers'' series, with a how to watch box. (Dayton Daily News)

   CHILDREN OF THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT PACKAGE

   ATTENTION EDITORS: Atlanta Journal Constitution reporter John
Blake has interviewed several men and women about growing up in the
1950s and '60s as children of the civil rights movement. The people
at the center of the struggle led dramatic, often dangerous, lives.
So, too, did their kids. The children of the movement _ the
offspring of black militants, nonviolent activists and even
segregationist leaders _ are now adults. They have followed many
roads in recent years. Some continue to carry on their parents'
work. Others want only to forget their childhood. Blake profiled
nine of them.

   The story is embargoed until Sunday, Sept. 10, but will move by
Friday evening. PHOTOS are available.

   Stories include:

   CIVILRIGHTS-CHILDREN _ Ericka Brown-Abram thinks she had a
typical childhood. Her mother's friends were killed in police
shootouts. Her family lived under FBI surveillance. She was
constantly shadowed by a bodyguard, even when she ran after the
neighborhood ice cream truck. Brown, 30, the daughter of a Black
Panther Party leader, once thought there was nothing unusual about
growing up in a communal home and attending a grade school where
students read Mao Tse-Tung's Red Book. ``A lot of people had this
swashbuckling idea of the Panthers,'' she said. ``But when you're a
child it all seemed normal.'' Nothing was normal, though, about
growing up in the 1950s and '60s as a child of the civil rights
movement. The people at the center of the struggle led dramatic,
often dangerous, lives. So, too, did their kids. These children of
the movement _ the offspring of black militants, nonviolent
activists and even segregationist leaders _ are now adults. The
Children of the Movement have followed many roads in recent years.
Some continue to carry on their parents' work. Others want only to
forget their childhood. Here are the stories of eight of them.
(Blake, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS

   WITH THE FOLLOWING PROFILES:

   _ Ericka Brown-Abram _ Daughter of Black Panther Elaine Brown.

   _ Albert Vivian _ Son of Rev. C.T. Vivian, a leader in the
Southern Christian Leadership Conference.

   _ Peggy Wallace _ Daughter of the late Alabame Gov. George
Wallace.

   _ Warith Deen Mohammed _ Son of Elijah Muhammed Sr., leader of
the Nation of Islam.

   Chevara Orrin and Bacardi Jackson _ Daughters of Rev. James
Bevel, a key aide to the Rev. Martin Kuther King, Jr.

   Ross Barnett Jr. _ son of Mississippi Gov. Ross Barnett, a
dedicated segregationist.

   END OF PACKAGE

   GLOBAL-WARMING _Arctic sea ice has thinned by 40 percent in the
last 30 years. This summer, there was open water at the North Pole.
From the Andes to the Alps, mountain glaciers are retreating. And
across North America, from the fire-scorched West to the
drought-parched Southeast, the last year of the millenium has given
millions a summer of discontent. As the signs of a warmer world
grow more apparent, there are some nagging new questions about ways
to prevent it. A new analysis by NASA physicist James Hansen, one
of the first scientists to sound the alarm over global warming 20
years ago, suggests that industrialized nations struggling to
implement a reduction in carbon dioxide emissions called for under
the proposed 1997 Kyoto Protocol, may be pursuing the wrong
villains in the global greenhouse mystery. (Toner, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   FAT-CRUISE _ Fighting the battle of the bulge onboard: ``Take
two pairs of pants,'' friends who are cruise veterans advised when
they found out about my plans for a seven-day Caribbean voyage. A
pair you can wear now and one the next size up for after I'd
crossed the sea of indulgence, they said. No way, I replied. Weigh,
they said. Weigh before you go. Weigh after you come back. You'll
be five pounds heavier. And I thought you were supposed to leave
your cares behind on a cruise. Would this be the diary of a
disaster at sea? (AMiller, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH
ILLUSTRATION.

best cruises for different types of travelers _ families,

   HOT-ARIZONA _ The first thing that hits you about Phoenix is the
heat. Yes, it's dry heat, whatever that means, but 113 degrees _
the high during a recent trip _ is still hot by any standard. But
there's some good news. The temperatures will soon start to get
cooler, travelers will look for an interesting place to go, and
Phoenix is a nice, affordable destination with more than enough to
do. (Marcano, Dayton Daily News)

   INTERNATIONAL

   MEXICO-HUMANRIGHTS MEXICO CITY _ Pressure is mounting for
Mexican President-elect Vicente Fox to look into Mexico's record of
human rights abuses. Prompted by the recent arrest of an Argentine
here suspected of torture in his home country, a group of people
with ``disappeared'' family members have resurrected their own
fight for justice. They accuse high-ranking officials of the
Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) of repressive acts over the
party's 71-year rule. Pressure is also on to review other cases _ a
peasant environmentalist and an Army colonel _ human rights group
believe are unjustly imprisoned now.

   WAN: Location, Atlanta; Category, International; Subcategory,
Other.

   WRITER/EDITOR: (Ferriss, Cox News Service) WITH PHOTOS

   RUSSIA-INTERNET MOSCOW _ Under a new law, every communications
and Internet provider in Russia must install a program designed by
the Federal Security Service, or FSB, to allow the intelligence
agency to monitor e-mail and Internet traffic by users. Not only
does the Internet provider have to allow the FSB access to their
network, but the companies have to pay for the installation and
training for these officers to do their dirty work. Human rights
organizations are up in arms, arguing it's a further sign that the
country has slipped back into a Soviet mode of control. (Coker, Cox
News Service) WITH PHOTOS.

   ISRAEL-DEFENSE _ JERUSALEM _ In a country flush with military
bravado, it figures that Israeli tourist shops would offer an array
of army ball caps and fatigue T-shirts. ``America don't worry,''
quips one T-shirt around a drawing of an F-16 jet. ``Israel is
behind you.'' In truth, of course, it's the other way around.
American aid makes up about a quarter of Israel's defense budget,
including nearly half its equipment, comes free from America. But,
even as Israeli officials prepare to ask for increases in aid with
President Clinton's encouragement, some say that Israel's defense
dependence on American aid may be doing more harm than good. WAN:
Location, Atlanta; Category, International; Subcategory, Other.

   (Kaplow, Cox News Service)

   ISRAEL-USAID _ TEL AVIV _ Israel, which has a per capita income
greater and Greece and Spain, receives some $3 billion from the
United States annually _ about a quarter of the total U.S. aid
budget. With a possible Mideast peace on the horizon, that figure
could grow by billions more over the next decade. But should it?
Analysts, officials and American Israel backers see the aid as an
investment that reaps priceless returns. A growing number of that
same group are beginning to question Israel's reliance on American
largesse, however. (Kaplow, Cox News Service)

   CENSUS-ADJUST _ A federal lawsuit against the state of Virginia
is emerging as the all-important test case in the politically
charged issue of whether states next year can use raw census
results instead of statistically adjusted counts to redraw
legislative districts. A dozen major U.S. cities and counties have
joined the fight against a Virginia law passed this year by the
GOP-dominated legislature. Urban areas, with large minority
populations traditionally undercounted by the census, fear the
Virginia law will set a national precedent. (Holmes, Cox News
Service)

   Eds: Moving Thursday.

   WAN: Atlanta, National, U.S. Government

   SLAUGHTER-HONORS _ATLANTA _ J. C. Slaughter, 78, a black veteran
of World War II who won the purple heart and combat infantry badge,
was court martialed and dishonorably discharged after he refused a
direct order to return to the front lines. Slaughter was seriously
wounded and knew he'd be unable to keep up with his unit. Rcently,
through his daughter's efforts, the Army reopened Slaughter's case
and exonerated him, giving him an honorable discharge and veteran's
benefits. (Davis, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   VA-SENATE _ The Senate race in Virginia is shaping up as one of
the tightest in the country and a key factor in control of the
chamber next year. A veteran Democrat, incumbent Charles Robb, is
facing a popular former Republican governor, George Allen. (Dart,
Cox News Service)

   Eds: Moving Thursday.

   CHENEY _WASHINGTON _ Cursory looks at Dick Cheney's voting
record reveal a very conservative record on certain social issues.
But examining his full record across a broad spectrum illustrates
he was even more of a voice in the wilderness. (Sherman, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   TEEPEN-COLUMN _ George W. Bush is back in full-smirk mode now
that he's muddled the issue over presidential campaign debates. He
appears to think he has muddled it successfully, and perhaps he
has.Didn't Al Gore say he would debate Bush any time anywhere and
isn't he now, just as Bush charges, refusing to do just that?
Indeed. But Gore's rhetorical sally assumed Bush would first buy
into the debates that the presidential debate commission would set
up. After all, every candidate since 1988 had, including daddy
Bush. (Tom Teepen is national correspondent for Cox Newspapers.)
MOVES THURSDAY.

   KLEINBERG-COLUMN _ All along I knew that Patty the Postal Lady
was not a latent killer. Patty delivers the mail to my house.
Often, we chat. Sometimes about the rock music she has bellowing
from the portable radio in her little truck, sometimes about other
things. But I never envisioned that one troubled day she would show
up back at the post office, automatic weapon in hand, and
rat-a-tat-tat a bunch of co-workers. (Kleinberg, Cox News Service.)
MOVED THURSDAY.

   GLASS-COLUMN _ (Andy Glass is a columnist for Cox News Service
in the Washington bureau.) MOVES THURSDAY.

   DAYTON END OF LIFE SERIES

   Beginning Sunday, the Dayton Daily News begins a five-part
series called ``Letting Go: Choices at the end of life.'' It's all
about end-of-life issues, from hospice care to talking to doctors
and families, support groups and health industry issues.

   The series is running in conjunction with a PBS Series by Bill
Moyers called ``On Our Terms'' that is running in most markets from
Sunday, Sept. 10 through Wednesday Sept. 13, but the stories can
stand alone.

   The stories will be available via the Budget Tool with a run
date that corresponds to the day the story is moving.

LIVING page for Tuesday, Sept, 19. That page will be available on
Friday, Sept. 15 at 2 p.m.

   SUNDAY, SEPT. 10

   END-OF-LIFE _ DAYTON, Ohio _ The morning after Chuck Gross's
90th birthday bash, he woke up with severe chest pain from a
fracture in his spine. His doctor guessed it had been caused by the
spread of his prostate cancer, first diagnosed eight years before.
But Gross declined to be treated or even tested for metastatic
disease. He felt the time had come to leave this life gracefully,
and on his own terms. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 80 inches

   WITH PHOTOS

continuing at 9 p.m. CT Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, WPTD,
Channel 16, will air On Our Own Terms: Moyers on Dying. This PBS
series by Bill and Judith Davidson Moyers examines the options
available for the terminally ill. The series will be repeated at
various times throughout the week. Each part focuses on different

   MONDAY, SEPT. 11

   END-DYING _ DAYTON, Ohio _ The cost of dying. Trying to keep
people alive in the last months of life is bankrupting our health
care system as scientific advances outpace our ability to pay for
them. But the alternative of allocating what we do and don't pay
for raises lots of thorny ethical issues. Local health care
organizations have put together a consortium of ethicists to
address these problems, and we talk to them about a number of
issues. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 45 to 50 inches. WITH PHOTO

   END-DIRECTIVES _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Living wills, advance
directives, durable powers of attorney. What are they and what do
you need to be doing to make sure your wishes about dying are
followed. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News)15 inches

   END-SERIES _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Short story explaining the Bill
Moyers' series, with a how to watch box. (Dayton Daily News)

   END-SERIESBOX _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Furniture about the series,
what's coming up. (Dayton Daily News)

   TUESDAY, SEPT. 12

   END-DRDEATH _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Doctors are trained to prevent
death, not cooperate with it. The result is that they're at
cross-purposes with hospice care. By overestimating life
expectancies, they both mislead patients and families and disable
the hospice concept. It's generally agreed that doctors need more
training in end-of life care, particularly the pain-relief and
psychological aspects, but aside from that, there is an honest
dispute as to where doctors belong on the spectrum from defying
death to embracing hospice care. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 50
inches

   WEDNESDAY, SEPT. 13

   END-MONEYSTRAIN _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Doctors didn't discover Sandra
Lee Hughes' lung cancer until the disease had reached her brain and
paralyzed her legs. At 43, and with two young daughters in her
care, Hughes suddenly had no job and no family support system at a
time when she was facing a terminal disease. She called on her
estranged husband, an unemployed Fairborn resident from whom she
had been separated for six years. He moved her from Alabama to his
home in Fairborn, where family members, including Hughes'
14-year-old daughter, Jennifer, took turns caring for her in a
tiny, ramshackle house. For hours at a time, Jennifer found herself
alone with her mother and, at times, no food to eat. A family
doctor recommended Hospice of Dayton, and soon the agency's home
health aides were there not only to care for Hughes but to make
sure there was enough medical supplies and food in the home.
Hospice never charged the family a penny, but the agency must rely
on donations from the community to help families like Sandra's.
Once she saw that her daughters would be taken care of, Hughes
decided to let go, calling out to Jennifer one night to say
``goodbye.'' (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily News) 25 inches

   WITH PHOTO

   END-MONEYSTRAINSIDE _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Tips on how to ease the
financial strain and utilize community resources for families
dealing with the death of a loved one. (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily
News) 10 inches

   END-VETS _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Harold Johnson served his country
proudly in Vietnam as an infantry sergeant, only to be exposed by
his own government to a toxic chemical, Agent Orange, that years
later would lead to lung cancer. Johnson, 51, is now in the end
stages of that disease. He says he's no longer bitter about what
happened to him in Vietnam, and that he looks forward to ``meeting
the Lord.'' And he's also grateful to the hospice and palliative
care program at the Dayton VA, which has provided his end-of-life
care free of charge. The VA here wants to get the word out: it
provides a wide array of end-of-life services to eligible veterans,
and at no cost. (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily News) 25 inches. WITH PHOTO

   CHILDREN OF THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT PACKAGE

   ATTENTION EDITORS: Atlanta Journal Constitution reporter John
Blake has interviewed several men and women about growing up in the
1950s and '60s as children of the civil rights movement. The people
at the center of the struggle led dramatic, often dangerous, lives.
So, too, did their kids. The children of the movement _ the
offspring of black militants, nonviolent activists and even
segregationist leaders _ are now adults. They have followed many
roads in recent years. Some continue to carry on their parents'
work. Others want only to forget their childhood. Blake profiled
nine of them.

   The story is embargoed until Sunday, Sept. 10, but will move by
Friday evening. PHOTOS are available.

   Stories include:

   CIVILRIGHTS-CHILDREN _ Ericka Brown-Abram thinks she had a
typical childhood. Her mother's friends were killed in police
shootouts. Her family lived under FBI surveillance. She was
constantly shadowed by a bodyguard, even when she ran after the
neighborhood ice cream truck. Brown, 30, the daughter of a Black
Panther Party leader, once thought there was nothing unusual about
growing up in a communal home and attending a grade school where
students read Mao Tse-Tung's Red Book. ``A lot of people had this
swashbuckling idea of the Panthers,'' she said. ``But when you're a
child it all seemed normal.'' Nothing was normal, though, about
growing up in the 1950s and '60s as a child of the civil rights
movement. The people at the center of the struggle led dramatic,
often dangerous, lives. So, too, did their kids. These children of
the movement _ the offspring of black militants, nonviolent
activists and even segregationist leaders _ are now adults. The
Children of the Movement have followed many roads in recent years.
Some continue to carry on their parents' work. Others want only to
forget their childhood. Here are the stories of eight of them.
(Blake, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS

   WITH THE FOLLOWING PROFILES:

Wallace.

   _ Warith Deen Mohammed _ Son of Elijah Muhammed Sr., leader of

   GLOBAL-WARMING _Arctic sea ice has thinned by 40 percent in the
last 30 years. This summer, there was open water at the North Pole.
From the Andes to the Alps, mountain glaciers are retreating. And
across North America, from the fire-scorched West to the
drought-parched Southeast, the last year of the millenium has given
millions a summer of discontent. As the signs of a warmer world
grow more apparent, there are some nagging new questions about ways
to prevent it. A new analysis by NASA physicist James Hansen, one
of the first scientists to sound the alarm over global warming 20
years ago, suggests that industrialized nations struggling to
implement a reduction in carbon dioxide emissions called for under
the proposed 1997 Kyoto Protocol, may be pursuing the wrong
villains in the global greenhouse mystery. (Toner, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

they found out about my plans for a seven-day Caribbean voyage. A
pair you can wear now and one the next size up for after I'd
crossed the sea of indulgence, they said. No way, I replied. Weigh,

your cares behind on a cruise. Would this be the diary of a
disaster at sea? (AMiller, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH
